name: Liz Schieler
comment info:
I noticed that the lowest group was just short of $40K and the highest was about $155K.  I also noticed that the first 4 groups are about what most people would consider basic human needs and/or civil rights topics.  Finally, I noticed that the other topics are all about either mental/emotional stress/struggles or physical stress/struggles.

I wonder what the biggest challenge with travel would be for the highest income group.  I also wonder if the pressures and stresses listed were self-imposed or if they were imposed by others.  Finally, I wonder if there were any students that applied outside of the $40K - $155K range and what their topics were.

I think this relates to me and my community of students because it is helpful for everyone to be aware of the different struggles people face based on their level of income.  Over the years, it has become extremely hard for students to think outside of their own situation, so this graph would help them do that.  It may also help students realize how big of a challenge the question is asking for when they go to write their own college application essays.

The title I would give this graph is: "Life's challenges, by household income, as told by University of California applicants"

name: Nicholas
comment info: The first thing that I noticed, while it is subjective, is that as household income increases the college essay topics become “less serious”. What I mean by this is the difference between the topics of economic insecurity, abuse, and domestic instability falling to households with an income of 65k and under, while topics like travel, sports, and failure fall to households with an income of 125k and over. While looking at the graph, I also noticed that the vast majority of the essay topics had some form of negative connotation. I wonder what percentage of students’ essays that were surveyed for this fell into Other/Miscellaneous categories. I also noticed that the essay topics were gathered for a specific essay prompt that applicants may answer, out of many different options. I wonder how this fact affected the range of essay topics and what the data would look like if it included other prompts. Since this data was compiled for only the University of California applicants, I wonder how this same data breaks down for different schools or even by state.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Nicholas I think it's great that you brought up the idea of maybe taking location into account in what topics might be written about.  To add to that I think that not only geographic location but also size of town might affect that as well.  I currently teach in a rural setting where we are over an hour away from the nearest "box" store such as Walmart.  The challenges faced by those in a small rural setting may be very different than those faced in an urban environment.  That would be an interesting thing to look at in the future.

name: L BOZO
comment info:
One of the things that really interested me was the various demands and problems in relation to the income levels. In lower income essays, they mainly talked about immediate problems that are much more likely to happen when you are poor, like the chances of abuse, hunger, and lack of affordable housing. In middle class essays, they mainly talked about emotional difficulties, which are likely to happen if you're pressured by those around you to rise up the social ladder and become wealthier. And in wealthier families, most of their problems stem from their wealth, like maybe a problem during a vacation or a sports dispute, extras that the other families would be less likely to afford. 

One category that really stuck out to me was discrimination, and how it was firmly in the middle of the income range. I guess maybe when people of color are a part of the middle class, they are likely to live in suburbs, which might be more discrminatory to them. Or, maybe it's because if you're an ambitious woman or POC or both, you might be more likely to encounter bigots who will try to slow you down.

This isn't really answering the questions, but were observations that I made. If there isn't already a title for it, it would be "Money doesn't always buy true happiness"

name: Sebastian P.
comment info: One thing that I noticed about the graph was the note at the bottom which mentions how authors manually classified essays and how the incomes were self-reported, while this doesn't necessarily invalidate the data, it does mean it should all be taken with a grain of salt because the data could be wrong. For example, asking students to classify their own essays means that the students could simply classify their essays incorrectly, or in a way that doesn't line up with the other essays. Another issue with self-reported data is sample bias because if responding or sending in an essay was optional, then the only responses you'd get are from the kind of people who would actually respond, and with something like income, in particular, it is possible that certain income groups are as a whole more likely to respond which messes up the data in a way that has to be considered while analyzing the graph.

replies.comment info: @Sebastian P. You make some very valid points. How data is gathered should influence the type of conclusions we can draw from the data or at least make us question the types of conclusions that can be drawn. Assuming that the self-reporting was mostly accurate, what kinds of conclusions could you draw?

name: Sharon HESSNEY
comment info:
Correlation?  Not here!

Many of you are using the word correlation to describe the relationship between challenged identified in college essays and the applicant’s family income. Correlation is only used with quantitative variables, like height or number of text messages.  Since college essay topics are categories, we cannot use the word correlation.  Instead, we say that the essay topics and income are associated.

The more serious responses to personal challenges (economic/material insecurity, abuse, immigration, and death) tend to be from lower-income homes. I was also surprised that discrimination/stereotypes came from relatively higher-income households. 

2. What do you wonder?

Why did they show the graph the way they did, it could be misleading because it is a list on the side of different subjects in order of income answers with a significant negative slope to income. however, these topics are different and shouldn't look like a comparative slope. (I would have don't this as a bar graph, not a scatterplot)

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?

It is important to know what kids find as struggles in a community to really find their own privilege... some people wrote about sports and travel while others wrote about abuse and death. This doesn't mean that there isn't abuse in higher-income households in any way but it is a good measure to check your privilege.

4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea

challenges vs. income

replies.comment info: @Katherine You definitely noticed that topics seemed to be grouped or correspond to income. One note about your use of the term scatterplot. Altough this graph is made of dots, that does not make it a scatterplot.  To be a scatterplot, there needs to be two numerical variables. Income is numerical.  Is essay topic numerical?  Perhaps a bar graph would have been better to show the variation in income.

name: Amirah Redwing
comment info:
1) I think that the most notable aspect of this graph is the range of topics from more serious issues to essays that showcase positive experiences. I think that this graph further reflects our society at large, and accurately illustrates the hardships of living in a capitalist society and the privileges of the upper-class.

2) As a country that supposedly takes pride in its students, achievements, and academia, why do mere teenagers have to share their hardships as fairy tales, essentially entertaining the college board, to simply take the next step in pursuing knowledge of their choosing? 

3) I think this article relates to my community because many students too feel disdain for the American education system and do hope to see some change. 

4) A large reason I want to go to college is less so that I can continue to educate myself on subjects that I'm passionate about and more-so so that I can “get a degree, a good job, and have an honest income” as we are told to do so. In fact the careers I'm interested in, the majors I wish to pursue, don’t provide enough to live ideally and stably as one would like. I also don’t wish to subject myself to societal labels such as “uneducated” for choosing not to further an education that could potentially strip me of the wealth I'm told to go after.

Headline: Mom, is my college essay done?

name: Sharon HESSNEY
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the relationship between the college essay subjects students chose to answer the prompt “Describe the most significant challenge you have faced and the steps you have taken to overcome this challenge” and their family’s household income. Evidence was gathered in November 2016, before the pandemic, from 60,000 University of California applications.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?”, “What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in this graph. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included thus graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”

In lower-income communities' violence and abuse is unfortunately more common, which is where those who fall into poverty tend to end up. name: MHS Block 6
comment info:
Headline: Deeper Pockets, Lesser Struggles

What we notice: 
- People with lower incomes write about problems that affect their livelihood (Such as abuse and domestic instability)
- 3,000 out of 60,000 essays were analyzed 
- Higher-income essay topics were very broad
- Topics like sports and travel make sense for higher household incomes
- There is a trend line on the graph
- The wealthier the applicants got the more trivial their essay topic

What we wonder: 
- What does failure mean in this graph?
- How many essays are in each category? 
- Would results be the same if we used a larger sample size?
- Which group had the highest acceptance rate? 
- Do people with certain incomes write about similar struggles? 
- How would data change if we looked internationally?
- Do minorities write about discrimination more than other topics? 

How this graph relates to us and our community:
- Many of us will write college essays soon
- We can learn to deviate from the norm for our income
- We can learn which one is the most successful

comment info:
1. From observing the graph, it is evident that students with low reported household incomes often come from greater hardships than students with high reported household incomes. For example, students who live in a household of well over 150,000 dollars will express minor problems in their college essay, with the main issue associated as "travel (unrelated to immigration and relocation)." However, students who make a reported household income of lower than 80,000 dollars will write an actual essay pertaining to immigration. While each subject is unique, it is clear that lower income households write more momentous topics.

name: Sophia Mura
comment info:
What do I notice?

I notice that the lower a family’s income, the more likely a student is to discuss financial insecurity, abuse, domestic instability, and immigration in their college essays. The higher a family’s income, the more likely a student is to discuss travel, failure, sports, and emotions.

What do I wonder?

I wonder how income specifically prompts students to discuss certain topics in their college essays. For example, having low income for a family can cause stress on parents and children; never knowing if there will be food on the table can lead to abuse and poor domestic relationships if stress is not dealt with in a healthy way. Perhaps students with low domestic income have immigrants for parents and therefore have less economic opportunity than kids who have native-born parents. On the other hand, students with a higher domestic income probably had a higher education than students with a lower domestic income, as a result, there are higher expectations for those students to succeed, and they probably discuss their fear of failure on their college essays. They have the money to participate in sports and discuss their hardships/ experiences in the game. Maybe they aspire to travel which is something students with lower income couldn’t dream of.

How does this relate to me?

My community for the most part is middle class, so perhaps the hardships we discuss on our college essays will not be about money.

Title: Does Financial Insecurity Lead to Maturity?
